newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore stocks flat, Want Want goes ex-bonus.
newsitem.headline: Singapore stocks flat, Want Want goes ex-bonus.

text.p: The Singapore stock market was flat at mid-morning on Tuesday, with activity lacklustre and fresh trading incentives missing, dealers said.
At 0200 GMT, the Straits Times Industrials Index was down 2.57 points at 2,027.64. Volume was a meager 16.9 million shares with 70 gainers against 51 losers.

The 1.1 percent year-on-year increase in Singapore's April production output after five months of falls failed to inspire trading as the rise was anticipated after the release of the April non-oil domestic exports in late May.
Snaker maker Want Want Holdings adjusted for a bonus issue.
It was trading US$0.42 lower at US$3.10, which equated to US$3.60 after adjusting to the isssue. GK Goh Research kept its "buy" recommendation for Want Want.
"Fundamentally, it is still very good. Its China operations are doing very well," said GK Goh analyst Teo Hiang Boon.
"Buy into six months or more time frame given it will post the fastest earnings growth among the big-cap food and beverage companies." Its price target was US$3.80 after adjusting to the bonus issue.
Malaysian timber firm North Borneo, focus of many merger rumours, rose S$1.20 to S$21.40. -- Angela Tan (65 8703083)
